page.title: 14THE CHURCH IN BRANSCOMBE
page.content: The church dates from Saxon times and there is evidence of this in masonry found at the base of the turret staircase of the tower.The tower and part of the nave are late Norman.In the 13th century Walter Branscombe added a North and South transcept. Many more additions and alterations were made,then in the 16th century much damage and destruction took place. Inside the church is a fine oak gallery given by a wealthy local family. Before 1900 it had high pews known as horsebox pews. These were replaced with the pews existing today. The tower is Norman. It has a three decker pulpit. On the outbreak of the second world war 700 detailed pictures of it were taken as a precaution against its destruction so that it is probably the best documented church in England.
